objtitle.title: Sketch for Engraving of Michelangelo after Fuseli, on a Drawing by Fuseli

objdescid.origination: William Blakeinventor, delineator. The pencil sketch, upper right, of the figure's legs and lower torso is attributed to Blake.
Henry Fuseliinventor, delineator. The pen and ink drawing of the figure is by Fuseli.
John Linnellauthor. The inscription lower left is attributed to Linnell.
objdescid.compdate: c. 1788Fuseli's imaginary portrait of Michelangelo, with the legs added, was engraved by Blake and first published in Henry Fuseli, Lectures on Painting, 1801. There is good circumstantial evidence, however, for concluding that both the pen and ink drawing by Fuseli and Blake's added sketch were executed at a much earlier date. The drawings are on the same paper of approximately the same size (within 1 mm. in height and 6 mm. in width) as Fuseli's pen and ink preliminary sketch for the frontispiece, engraved by Blake, for John Caspar Lavater, Aphorisms on Man, 1788, translated and edited by Fuseli. The brown ink and style of execution are the same in the two Fuseli drawings. The fragmentary watermark in this drawing of Michelangelo is very probably the upper part of the shield and GR watermark in the drawing for the Aphorisms preliminary drawing. These two leaves were almost certainly cut from the same larger sheet of paper. Fuseli may very well have drawn his portrait of Michelangelo with the intention of having it engraved for an illustration to his own Aphorisms on Art, left unpublished until after Fuseli's death. Thus, a date of c. 1788 for these drawings by Fuseli and Blake, and perhaps even for Blake's execution of the Michelangelo portrait engraving, seems probable. This dating was first proposed in Ruthven Todd, "Two Blake Prints and Two Fuseli Drawings," Blake Newsletter 5.3 (winter 1971-72): 173-81.

objinfo.objsize: 9.0 x 5.1 cm.This is the size of Blake's pencil sketch.
objinfo.medium: pencilThe main drawing is by Henry Fuseli, executed in pen and brown ink. The inscription lower left, attributed to John Linnell is in pencil.
objinfo.watermark: The fragmentary watermark is probably the finial on the shield and GR watermark in Henry Fuseli's preliminary sketch for the frontispiece, engraved by Blake, for John Caspar Lavater, Aphorisms on Man, 1788. See the note on Date, above.

provenance.note: Acquired from Blake or his wife Catherine by John Linnell (possibly one of the "two [drawings] by Fuseli" acquired by Linnell from Catherine Blake, 29 Jan. 1829, with a "Drawing of Heads" by Blake for £1—see Bentley, Records, page 792, and the Textual Transcription of Linnell's inscription); the dealer Ernest Seligmann by 1970; acquired by Robert Essick, Aug. 1972 ($2952).

desc.objtitle:
Sketch for Engraving of Michelangelo after Fuseli, on a Drawing by Fuseli,
object 1 (Butlin 172)

objnote.p: Only the pencil sketch upper right is attributed to Blake; the main drawing in pen and brown ink is by Henry Fuseli. Blake probably executed this sketch of the figure's lower torso and legs in preparation for his engraving of the complete figure. For further information, see Work Information.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the upper right corner of a leaf containing a pen-and-ink figural drawing by Fuseli, a second figure, drawn in pencil by Blake, visible from the waist down stands facing right. This drawing by Blake is very probably an attempt to sketch out the lower part of the figure's body in preparation for engraving the full-length portrait (see the Work Information page). We know from that engraving and from Linnell's inscription on the drawing (see that Textual Transcription) that the figure is Michelangelo. He appears to wear shoes and a knee-length coat and breeches(?), suggesting he is male. His left foot is extended in front of his right with a slightly bent knee. His bent right arm is visible by his side, and he may hold something in his right hand, though this object is indistinguishable.
